events.summary: Juan reunites with Isabel in their private chambers at the Toledo Alcazar after arriving from the Ronda campaign. He tells her about declaring Islam finished in Ronda, the proud widow who chose exile over life under Christian rule, and the safe passage offered to those who left. Isabel processes the complexity of Muslim subjects living under Christian governance. They pray together in Isabel's Portuguese chapel corner, where Juan's heartfelt prayer reveals the depth of his love, moving Isabel to tears. They retire to bed together.

Chapter 24: In Toledo's Embrace

PART I: THE QUIET HOURS (October 17, Evening)

Their chambers in the Alcázar feel impossibly peaceful after months of campaign camps and fortress walls. The evening light filtering through the high windows is soft, golden—so different from the harsh Andalusian sun.

Isabel sits in the chair by the Portuguese chapel corner, one hand resting on her swollen belly, watching you with an expression caught between contentment and lingering disbelief. The carved Virgin Mary you gave her in August stands in its place of honor, surrounded by fresh flowers and well-used prayer cushions.

"I kept thinking," she says quietly, "that you wouldn't really come back. That something would happen—some battle, some treachery. Every messenger who arrived at the gates, my heart would stop." She touches the Virgin Mary's base. "I must have prayed the rosary a thousand times these past two months."

The baby moves visibly beneath her gown—a rolling motion, a stretching limb. Isabel's face softens with wonder, the way it always does when it happens. "The physicians say everything is progressing well. The baby's strong. Active. They think..." She pauses, almost shy. "They think it might be a boy, from how I'm carrying. But they're not certain."

Outside, the city of Toledo settles into evening routines. Distant sounds of vendors closing their stalls, church bells marking vespers, the general hum of a city that doesn't know war is still raging three hundred miles south.

Isabel looks at you, really looks at you—studying your face the way she couldn't in the courtyard with everyone watching. "You're different," she observes. "Not the armor or the dust. Something in your eyes. What happened at Ronda?"
I tell her about Ronda and how I declared Islam finished there. I tell her about the widow who stormed off furiously instead of staying in the new situation.

"Islam... finished," she repeats softly, testing the words. Her brow furrows—not in anger, but in that thoughtful way she has when wrestling with something difficult. "An entire city. Thousands of souls, all baptized in a single decree."

She shifts in her chair, wincing slightly as the baby kicks. "I should be joyful. I am joyful that they've accepted baptism, that they can be saved now. But Juan..." She looks at you directly, her plain face earnest. "The woman who left—the widow. She chose exile over Christ. How many others stayed only because they had nowhere to go? Because the alternative was losing everything?"

But I always imagined... I don't know. Willing converts. Hearts genuinely turned. Not thousands baptized because a king commanded it."

She's not accusing—her tone is gentle, questioning. "Tell me you truly believe they can become good Christians. That this wasn't just... military necessity dressed in holy purpose."

Did you expect Grenada to convert willingly the moment I conquered them?

"No," she admits quietly. "I suppose I didn't think it through properly. In my prayers, I always imagined... victory. The cross raised over Granada. But I never truly considered what came after. The people still there, still living their lives, still believing what they've always believed."

She's silent for a moment, thinking. "You're right that I haven't met them. Any of them. I've lived my whole life in palaces and courts where everyone was Christian. Everyone I've ever known has been Christian." A rueful smile touches her lips. "I must seem terribly foolish to you."

The baby kicks again and she winces, adjusting her position. "Proud, you say. I can understand pride. The Portuguese are proud too—sometimes to our detriment." She considers this. "So they'll live as Muslims in a Christian kingdom. Pay taxes, obey laws, but keep their faith. And some, in time, may choose Christ of their own will."

Last year, she was the wife of the governor, a high position in society and her three boys had it good. Today, she is a single mother with no station. She has lost her position in society which relied solely on her husband and the position he had. Not only did he die, I took over the position as well. I offered her to stay, but it would be very hard. She refused, the loss too much to bear. I had hoped differently, but I do understand her. She was furious and hurt.

Isabel's face softens with understanding, and something like pain crosses it. Her hand goes to her belly protectively—an instinctive gesture.

She looks at you with new comprehension. "This is what you carry, isn't it? Not just the battles and the strategy, but... all of them. The widow and her sons. The people who stay because they have no choice. The ones who convert out of hope or fear or genuine faith, and you'll never know which."

A tear slips down her cheek unexpectedly. She brushes it away, almost annoyed with herself. "I'm sorry. The pregnancy makes me weep at everything. But I'm thinking of her—traveling somewhere with three children, no husband, no position. Starting over completely."

She reaches for your hand. "You did what you could. You offered her the chance to stay. But grief and pride and loss... those don't follow reason." Her voice is gentle. "Did you at least give her safe passage? Money for the journey?"

The question isn't accusatory—she trusts you did. But she needs to know this small mercy was shown.

I offered safe passage to everyone who wanted to leave. In fact, I am glad they left. Those who remained will not rebel and will live in peace.


Can we just pray together now Isabel? I want to rest and hold you afterwards.

Isabel's face transforms—relief and joy replacing the pensive worry. "Yes. Of course. I've been longing to pray with you again."

She rises from her chair with some effort, one hand supporting her belly, and moves to the chapel corner. She kneels carefully on one of the well-worn prayer cushions, then looks back at you with such open affection that it's almost startling to see on her usually reserved face.

"I've prayed alone every evening since you left," she says softly. "But it's not the same. This—" she gestures to the space beside her, "—this is what I've missed most."

She waits for you to join her, her hand already reaching for her rosary beads, her eyes already beginning to close in that peaceful way she has when preparing for prayer.

I sit beside her and lay my hand on her back for a moment.


Then I let her start the prayer.

Isabel's eyes close, and her voice—quiet, steady, intimate—begins the Ave Maria. You can feel the tension leaving her body under your hand as she settles into the familiar rhythm of prayer.

She leads through the evening prayers with practiced ease, her Portuguese accent softening the Latin. When she reaches the personal petitions, her voice becomes even quieter, more private:

"Blessed Mother, thank you for bringing him home safely. Watch over him still—the war is not finished. Protect him when he returns to it." A pause, her hand moving to her belly. "And this child... let it be healthy. Let me be strong enough for the birth. Let us be a family as you were with Joseph and our Lord."

Her voice catches slightly. "For all those in Ronda—Christian and Muslim alike—grant them peace. For the widow with three sons, wherever she goes... be her comfort."

She continues in silence for a time, lips moving soundlessly, fingers working through her rosary beads. The room fills with the peaceful quiet of shared prayer, the dying light through the windows painting everything in warm gold.

Finally, she crosses herself and opens her eyes, turning to look at you with such contentment that six months of marriage seem to dissolve into this single moment.

"Thank you," she whispers simply.

When you open your eyes, Isabel is looking at you. Tears stream down her face—not sad tears, but something deeper. Her hand finds yours and grips it tightly.

"Juan," she whispers, her voice thick with emotion. "I didn't know... I thought perhaps you saw me only as duty. As the alliance with Portugal. But you love me."

You lift her carefully—she's heavier with the pregnancy, but you manage—and carry her to the bed. She clings to you, still crying, half-laughing through her tears at your words.

Her voice breaks slightly. "You weren't performing duty. You weren't being the king. You were speaking from your heart to God, and you said—" She can't finish, overcome again.

"You said loving me was harder than the war," she whispers. "That you find it easy to be God's soldier, but hard to be away from me. Do you understand what that means? That I matter that much?"

She pulls you down to sit beside her. "I'm not being irrational. I'm just... I'm understanding the depth of it for the first time. And it makes everything—the waiting, the fear, all of it—it makes it bearable. Because we're carrying it together."

events.summary: Juan meets with Alvaro de Luna the morning after his arrival to discuss his strategic agenda: a vision of unified Iberia through multi-generational marriage alliances, the upcoming Cortes tax reform with the 7-8% base rate and service credits system, establishing a naval and trade policy to capitalize on captured Mediterranean ports, and the Perpetual Crusade Fund concept. Alvaro outlines a four-day Cortes strategy beginning with celebrating victories, distributing Granada lands, then presenting reform proposals.

exchanges.text: We sleep and rest and tomorrow I set up a meeting with Alvaro de Luna.

You wake to pale morning light and the sound of church bells marking prime. Isabel is still asleep beside you, one hand resting protectively on her belly even in sleep. The lines of worry that have marked her face these past months seem softer now.

You let her rest and dress quietly, servants moving efficiently to prepare you for the day. The armor and travel-stained clothes from yesterday have been cleaned and stored; today you're dressed as a king in his capital, not a crusader fresh from campaign.

Word is sent to Don Álvaro de Luna: the king requests his presence in the council chamber at his earliest convenience.

The response comes within the hour. The Constable will attend you immediately.

When Álvaro arrives, he looks remarkably well-rested for a man managing a kingdom. His dark eyes are sharp, assessing you quickly—noting, no doubt, that you look better than you did upon arrival last night. He bows formally.

"Your Majesty. I trust you and the Queen had a peaceful evening?" There's the faintest hint of knowing warmth in his voice—he genuinely approves of your marriage to Isabel, you've learned. "Welcome home. Toledo has felt your absence keenly these past two months."

He settles into the chair across from you, already pulling out several documents from the leather case he carries. "I have much to report—the Cortes preparations, correspondence from the armies, financial matters, and several... complications that have arisen. But perhaps you'd prefer to begin with your own news from Ronda? The reports that arrived were spectacular, but I'd value hearing the details directly."

He waits attentively, ready to discuss whatever you wish to prioritize.

I tell him everything that has happened so he is fully informed. I trust him implicitly.


Then, I set out what I want to discuss.


I have a vision of a unified Iberia. I want to discuss how I can unite all crowns. 
At the upcoming Cortes, I want to set up a system that will allow the nobles to continue to support conquest overseas. 
I also want to reform the tax code, like we discussed earlier. 8% tax on revenue for nobles where the proceeds go into an eternal crusade (or conquest treasury), and we use that money to fund future expansions against heathens and heretics. 
I want to discuss how we develop Castille's naval and trade policies now that we have taken most of the ports. This means more taxes and more control for me as well. 
I want to discuss how the letters to other christian nations are developping and if we have had any more foreign aid. 
I want to discuss the painting of my marriage that we have commissioned. Have we found a renaissance painter yet?

The unified Iberian vision requires careful diplomatic maneuvering. Marriage alliances could be key - particularly with the Infantes de Aragón situation and Navarre's position. I'll propose strategic connections that gradually consolidate power without creating immediate political backlash.

For the Cortes and conquest mechanism, we need a compelling framework that incentivizes nobles. The land distribution in Granada provides an excellent initial carrot, but we'll need a longer-term strategy that makes overseas conquest financially attractive. The proposed 8% tax could fund this, creating a perpetual conquest fund that gives nobles both risk and reward.

The tax reform is politically delicate. Nobles have historically been exempt, so this 8% will face resistance. I'll recommend a phased approach - perhaps starting lower, with clear benefits like first access to conquered lands, trading rights, and potential noble titles in new territories.

Our naval and trade policy must capitalize on our newly captured Mediterranean ports. We'll need significant infrastructure investment, but these ports offer unprecedented trade opportunities. I'll suggest detailed plans for customs, ship construction, and potential trade agreements with emerging maritime powers.

Foreign aid letters require a nuanced approach. We'll draft carefully worded missives that highlight our strategic importance and potential mutual benefits, without appearing desperate or weak.

The Renaissance painter commission is a subtle but important diplomatic and cultural move. I'll recommend seeking a painter who can capture not just images, but the emerging spirit of our expanding kingdom.

Álvaro listens intently as you recount everything—Ronda's negotiated surrender, Muhammad ibn Hariz's baptism, the widow's departure, Don Rodrigo's continuing operations. He takes notes occasionally, nodding at key points, his expression thoughtful.

When you lay out your agenda, he sets down his quill and looks at you for a long moment. Then he smiles—not his usual political smile, but something genuine and almost wondering.

"Your Majesty, when you left for Santiago two years ago, you were an eighteen-year-old idealist with a papal bull and a dream. Now you return speaking of unified Iberia, perpetual conquest treasuries, and Mediterranean trade policy." He shakes his head slightly. "The crusade has forged you into something remarkable. Very well. Let us address each matter systematically."

He pulls out a fresh sheet of parchment. "Unified Iberia. The most ambitious goal, and the longest timeline. Let me assess each crown honestly:"

"Aragon: The Infantes de Aragón situation is... complicated. King Alfonso V is your cousin, childless so far, focused on Mediterranean expansion toward Naples. The Infantes—Juan and Enrique—are his brothers but also your enemies from their rebellion. Paradoxically, if Alfonso dies without heir, Juan of Aragón inherits. Your enemy becomes king of Aragon." He pauses. "But there's another path: your children. If you have a daughter, she could be betrothed to Alfonso or his heir. If you have a son, he might marry an Aragonese princess. Two generations, perhaps three, but achievable through marriage."

"Portugal: You're already married to King João's daughter. If João has no male heir—and he has only daughters so far—Isabel or her sisters inherit. Your son could claim Portugal through his mother. But Juan," Álvaro's voice becomes careful, "Isabel will struggle with this. Portugal fought hard for independence from Castile. Proposing reunification, even gently, could damage your marriage. Tread carefully."

"Navarre: Small, weak, caught between France and Iberia. Conquerable militarily, but France would object. Better through marriage alliance. They're always looking for protection. Patient diplomacy, another generation or two."

He looks up. "Summary: Unified Iberia is a multi-generational project. You lay groundwork through marriages, alliances, and your children's betrothals. You won't see it completed, but your grandchildren might. Is that acceptable?"

"The Cortes and Overseas Conquest System." Álvaro taps his quill thoughtfully. "This is brilliant, actually. The nobles have tasted conquest—they've seen the land grants, the wealth, the glory. If you can institutionalize their desire for more, you create a self-perpetuating expansion mechanism."

"Here's what I propose: At the Cortes, after distributing Granada lands, you announce a new royal policy. Any future conquests—whether in Africa, the Atlantic islands, or elsewhere—will follow the same model. Nobles who contribute troops and funds receive proportional land grants in conquered territories. But—and this is key—participation is voluntary. No feudal obligations, just opportunity."

"Pair this with your tax reform. The 8% revenue tax funds a 'Royal Conquest Treasury.' Nobles pay into it, but they also benefit from it through land grants when conquests succeed. It's an investment scheme dressed in crusading rhetoric." He grins. "Some will hate it. But the ambitious ones—the Mendozas, the younger sons looking for estates—they'll love it."

"The challenge is the first part: getting them to accept the 8% tax at all."

"Tax Reform." Álvaro's expression becomes serious. "This is your biggest fight at the Cortes. Currently, nobles pay almost nothing—they're exempt from most taxation. You're proposing an 8% revenue tax. That's... substantial."

"Your advantages: First, you're distributing massive Granada land grants simultaneously. Carrot and stick together. Second, you frame it as crusade taxation, not general revenue. Third, you've just won the greatest military victory in a century—your prestige is at its peak. Fourth, the papal bull explicitly authorizes crusade taxation."

"Your disadvantages: Nobles will resist any new taxes instinctively. Some will argue they've already paid in blood—their knights died in Granada. Others will claim economic hardship. The traditional privileges of nobility include tax exemption."

"My recommendation: Present it as a limited, temporary measure initially—say, ten years to fund 'completion of the Reconquista and expansion into Africa.' Make it sound finite even though you intend it to be permanent. Get them used to paying it. Then, when renewal comes in 1441, it's already established practice." He smiles wryly. "It's easier to continue a tax than to create one."

"Also, consider graduated rates. The greatest nobles—dukes, counts—pay 8%. Lesser nobles pay less, say 5-6%. It reduces resistance from the minor nobility who have less to give."

"Expect a fight. Budget three, maybe four days of intense Cortes debate on this alone."

"Naval and Trade Policy." Álvaro becomes animated—this clearly excites him. "We've captured most of Granada's Mediterranean coast. Málaga is a superb port—one of the finest in Iberia. Vélez-Málaga, Marbella, the others—all functional harbors. This changes everything."

"Currently, Castilian maritime trade is minimal. We're a land power. But now we can develop a Mediterranean fleet for both war and commerce. I propose several measures:"

"First: Establish a Royal Maritime Office based in Málaga. Customs duties on all goods passing through our captured ports—say, 10% on imports, 5% on exports. This generates substantial revenue and gives you control over trade flows."

"Second: Encourage shipbuilding. Offer tax incentives to merchants who build ships in Castilian ports. We need a merchant fleet, not just warships."

"Third: Recruit experienced sailors and navigators. Málaga had a significant maritime population—many stayed after your terms. Use them. Also recruit from Genoa, Venice, Portugal. Your marriage to Isabel gives you Portuguese contacts."

"Fourth: Consider Atlantic exploration. The Portuguese are already pushing down the African coast—Henry the Navigator's project. If we develop naval capacity, we could sponsor similar expeditions. The Canary Islands, the Azores, perhaps beyond. But that's years away—focus on Mediterranean consolidation first."

He pulls out a document. "I've been corresponding with Genoese merchants. They're very interested in access to our new ports, especially if you guarantee security and reasonable customs rates. They could bring capital, expertise, ships. But they'll want privileges—tax breaks, legal protections. Worth negotiating?"

"Foreign Aid and Recruitment." Álvaro's expression becomes more reserved. "The letters have had... mixed results. The responses so far:"

"Portugal: King João sent polite congratulations on Ronda. No offer of troops or funds, but warm diplomatic language. He's pleased you're married to Isabel and that the crusade succeeds. He hints that if you need Portuguese naval assistance in the Mediterranean, he'd consider it—for appropriate compensation."

"Aragon: King Alfonso sent a terse acknowledgment. He congratulates your victory but makes no offer of aid. The subtext is clear: he's focused on Naples, not Granada. Also, the Infantes situation makes him wary of helping you."

"France: No response yet. Frankly, I don't expect one. They're embroiled in the Hundred Years' War with England. They have no attention to spare for Iberian matters."

"England: Also no response. Same reason as France—they're fighting each other."

"German principalities: I sent letters to several. One response so far, from the Duke of Bavaria. He sends 'spiritual support and prayers' but no material aid. He suggests we appeal to the Holy Roman Emperor, but Emperor Sigismund is elderly and distracted by Hussite heretics in Bohemia."

"Italian states: Mixed. Venice sends congratulations and trade proposals—they're merchants first. Genoa likewise. Milan's Duke Filippo Maria Visconti sends a personal letter praising your 'strategic brilliance' at Ronda and offers to send military advisors if you want them—Milanese condottieri captains who could teach modern Italian tactics. That might actually be valuable."

He sets down the papers. "The hard truth, Your Majesty: Foreign aid is minimal because everyone is busy with their own wars. But trade opportunities are substantial—Italian merchants want access to your ports, Portuguese want cooperation, etc. That's where the real benefit lies."

"The Marriage Painting." Álvaro brightens considerably—he's clearly pleased with this. "Yes. I've found someone exceptional."

"I sent inquiries to Flanders—that's where the finest painters are right now. The Flemish have developed revolutionary techniques with oil paints, incredible detail and realism. And I've secured the services of Jan van Eyck, court painter to Philip the Good, Duke of Burgundy."

"Van Eyck is expensive—500 florins for the commission, plus travel and accommodation costs. But he's worth it. His work is extraordinary—he painted the Duke of Burgundy's wedding portrait recently, and the detail is unlike anything I've seen. Every jewel, every thread of fabric, perfectly rendered. He's a master."

"He'll arrive in Toledo in late November, after the Cortes. He'll need you and Isabel to sit for him—perhaps a dozen sessions over two months. The final painting will be ready by spring 1432, after the baby is born. We could include the child if you wish, or keep it just you and Isabel."

Álvaro smiles. "It will be a masterpiece, Your Majesty. Something to hang in the Alcázar for centuries. Future generations will see you as you are now—young, victorious, at the height of your power."

He sets aside his documents and looks at you directly. "That's my assessment of all your proposals. Which do you want to discuss in more depth? The Cortes tax fight will be intense—we should strategize carefully. And the naval policy requires immediate decisions if we want to capitalize on our port captures."

"Portugal is already secured through Isabel—your father-in-law is allied to you. If João has no male heir, Isabel or her sisters could inherit. Your children might eventually unite both crowns through their mother's claim. But Juan," his voice becomes careful, "never mention this to Isabel directly. The Portuguese fought hard for independence. Even hinting at reunification will hurt your marriage."

"Navarre is small, weak—easier. But France would object to outright conquest. Better through diplomacy and marriage alliances over time."

He sets the document aside. "You're laying groundwork. Your grandchildren might see unified Iberia. That's acceptable, yes?"

The Cortes Tax Reform

Álvaro's expression becomes serious. "This is the fight. Everything we've planned comes to fruition here."

"The framework we developed: 7-8% base rate on actual current revenues, with substantial service credits. Every month of personal military service reduces the tax burden. Every hundred men provided and maintained earns significant credits. Maximum reduction up to half the total tax."

"This accomplishes multiple goals: It's genuinely fair—rewards those who actually fight. It eliminates the corruption where nobles claim service while charging the crown. It incentivizes exactly the warrior culture you want. And politically, it gives nobles a choice: fight and save money, or pay full rate."

"The assessment teams are ready—43 trained assessors. We'll start with the greatest houses to demonstrate the tax falls on those most able to pay: Mendoza, Álvarez de Toledo, Guzmán. Joint authority with ecclesiastical observers to prevent accusations of bias."

He taps the table. "Your advantages: First, you're distributing massive Granada land grants simultaneously. Carrot and stick together. Second, you frame it as crusade taxation under papal authority—the bull explicitly authorizes it. Third, your prestige is at its peak after Ronda. Fourth, nobles have tasted conquest and want more."

"Your challenge: Nobles will resist instinctively. Some will claim they've already paid in blood. Others will argue economic hardship. Traditional noble privilege includes tax exemption."

"I recommend framing it carefully at the Cortes: This is not a new burden, but a modernization. The old patchwork system—where the Duke of Medina Sidonia pays 1% while some lesser nobles pay 4%—is unjust and inefficient. We're creating equality before the law. Everyone pays the same percentage of actual revenue, with the same opportunity for service credits."

"Also emphasize the Perpetual Crusade Fund framing we discussed. This isn't just taxation—it's investment. Nobles who serve in future conquests earn land grants proportional to their contribution. They're paying into a system that rewards them."

He pauses. "Expect three, maybe four days of intense debate. Some great houses will resist loudly. But others—particularly ambitious younger sons and military families—will see the opportunity. The new Granada estates you're granting will be taxed at 3-4%, setting a modern standard. That creates pressure on old nobility to accept similar rates."

Naval and Trade Policy

"We've captured most of Granada's Mediterranean coast—this changes everything, just as we discussed. Málaga is a superb port. You can now develop real maritime power."

"I propose establishing a Royal Maritime Office based in Málaga. Customs duties on all goods—say 10% on imports, 5% on exports. This generates substantial revenue and gives you control over trade flows."

"Encourage shipbuilding with tax incentives. Recruit experienced sailors—many stayed in Málaga after your terms. Also recruit from Genoa, Venice, Portugal. Your marriage to Isabel gives you Portuguese contacts, and they're ahead of us in maritime development."

"The strategic shift we discussed is accelerating: Castile is moving from land power to naval power. After Granada falls, you won't need fifty noble armies. You'll need professional fleets and standing forces funded by trade revenue. The nobles don't see this yet—they still think in terms of castles and retinues. But within a generation, real power will flow through ports and ships, not feudal levies."

He grins slightly. "Which is why locking in their taxation now, while they still feel militarily relevant, is brilliant timing."

The Cortes Strategy

Álvaro leans forward. "Here's how I suggest you approach the Cortes:"

"Day One: Celebrate the victories. Ronda, the coastal conquests, Alcalá la Real. Remind them of the crusade's success. Let them feel the glory."

"Day Two: Distribute the Granada lands. Make this generous—reward those who fought. Create gratitude. Show that service to the crown brings tangible rewards."

"Day Three: Present the tax reform. Frame it as modernization and equality, paired with the service credit system. Emphasize the Perpetual Crusade Fund—this isn't extraction, it's investment in future conquests where they'll earn more land."

"Day Four (if needed): Negotiate with resistant houses individually. Remind them of their land grants. Point out that new Granada nobility pays 3-4%. Offer minor concessions to save face, but hold the line on the fundamental structure."

"The combination of gratitude from land grants, religious fervor from crusade success, your personal prestige after Ronda, and the service credit system should carry the day. But it will be a fight."

He sets aside his notes and looks at you directly. "I'll prepare detailed documentation for each proposal. We'll have three days before the Cortes to refine the presentations. And Juan—" he permits himself a slight smile, "—what you've accomplished this campaign season is extraordinary. You've conquered half of Granada in eight months, taken Ronda without a siege, and broken their raiding network. You're negotiating from a position of absolute strength."

"The Cortes will be difficult, but you'll prevail. The question is: which proposals do you want to prioritize if we need to make tactical concessions?"

FROM THE HOLY SEE - POPE MARTIN V'S FINAL LEGACY

Álvaro unfurls a papal letter with elaborate seals. "This arrived first, carried by special courier. The Pope is dying, Juan. Everyone in Rome knows it. And he's made your crusade his final act."

The Papal Letter (dated September 8, 1431):

To Our Most Beloved Son Juan, King of Castile and León, Supreme Commander of the Holy Crusade,

We write to you from Our sickbed, knowing Our days in this world grow short. But before We are called to Our reward, We give thanks to Almighty God for permitting Us to witness what We had scarcely dared hope: a true crusade, prosecuted with both holy zeal and Christian mercy, achieving victories that echo the greatest triumphs of Christendom.

Your victory at Alcalá la Real, the seventy souls who freely chose baptism after witnessing God's favor, the negotiated surrender of Ronda - these are not merely military achievements but proofs of Divine Providence working through you.

Therefore, in what may be Our final official act, We do decree:

First, from the Apostolic Treasury, an additional THIRTY THOUSAND FLORINS to sustain your holy work.

Second, We dispatch Our trusted servant Cardinal Pietro Donato to Granada as Papal Legate with full authority to represent the Holy See in all matters relating to the crusade. He carries Our blessing and Our mandate to support you in all things.

Third, We hereby proclaim that ANY CHRISTIAN, in any land, who contributes financially to the Granada Crusade shall receive the same plenary indulgence granted to those who take the cross personally. Let the faithful know that supporting this crusade with their treasure is spiritually equivalent to wielding the sword.

Fourth, We have written personally to every Christian monarch, not requesting but DEMANDING their support for your crusade. We have made clear that this is not one king's war but Christendom's obligation.

Dear son, when We met you in Rome and you knelt before Us offering everything, We saw in you what the Church desperately needs: a champion who fights with sword AND soul, who conquers with both courage and mercy. Continue this work. Complete it. Then, as you promised, carry Our banner wherever Christ's enemies threaten His flock.

We shall pray for you daily until We close Our eyes for the final time. And We have every confidence that when We stand before the Throne of Judgment, We shall be able to say: "Lord, I found You a champion, and gave him Your blessing."

Given at the Lateran Palace, this eighth day of September, Year of Our Lord 1431.

MARTIN V, Bishop of Rome, Servant of the Servants of God

Álvaro's voice is thick with emotion. "He's dying, and this is what he wanted his legacy to be. Not just the money—though thirty thousand florins is extraordinary—but the indulgences. Juan, he just made every Christian in Europe eligible for full crusade indulgences if they donate to Granada. He's weaponized the entire Church's spiritual authority for your cause."

He sets down the letter carefully. "Cardinal Donato is en route now. Should arrive within two weeks. A papal legate with full authority staying in Castile until Granada falls—that's unprecedented."

FROM FRANCE - CHARLES VII'S STRATEGIC INVESTMENT

Álvaro pulls out a letter sealed with the French royal arms. "This one surprised me. Charles VII has his hands full with England. But apparently, your success caught his attention."

The French King's Letter (dated September 15, 1431):

To Our Brother in Christ, Juan, King of Castile,

We have followed with great interest the reports of your crusade against the Moorish Kingdom. Your victory at Alcalá la Real and your capture of Ronda have demonstrated both military prowess and political wisdom that We find most impressive.

France knows well the cost of long wars against determined enemies. We have fought the English for decades. Your ability to achieve decisive victories while preserving your forces through strategic negotiation shows understanding of warfare's true nature that many commanders lack.

Therefore, We wish to support your crusade and establish friendship between our kingdoms:

First, from Our treasury, FORTY THOUSAND FLORINS as immediate contribution to your holy work.

Second, We dispatch THREE HUNDRED veteran soldiers - men who fought with Joan of Arc at Orléans and Paris, who know victory against overwhelming odds. They volunteer for crusade service under your command. Their captain, Jean de Metz, is a knight of proven valor who served the Maid personally.

Third, We send Our master siege engineer, Guillaume Balard, who has conducted fifteen successful sieges. He brings knowledge of the most modern techniques.

Fourth, We propose formal alliance between France and Castile against any Muslim power that threatens Christian lands. The Barbary corsairs raid our Mediterranean coast as they raid yours. Together, we could sweep them from the sea.

We look forward to closer relations between our kingdoms. A king who can conquer with both sword and diplomacy is a king We wish as friend.

Charles, by Grace of God King of France

Álvaro taps the letter. "Forty thousand florins. Three hundred veterans—real soldiers, not levies. And he's proposing alliance. Charles is looking ahead: if you complete Granada quickly, you become his potential partner for Mediterranean operations. He's investing in future cooperation."

He grins. "Also, sending Joan of Arc's own veterans? That's a propaganda gift. They're famous across Europe. Having them fight for you associates your crusade with hers."

FROM BURGUNDY - DUKE PHILIP'S CRUSADING VISION

Álvaro holds up an ornate letter. "Philip the Good. One of Europe's richest rulers. He's been talking about crusading for years but never acted. Your success seems to have inspired him."

Duke Philip's Letter (dated September 20, 1431):

To the Most Christian King Juan of Castile, Champion of the Faith,

Your Majesty's achievements in Granada have stirred Our heart profoundly. We have long dreamed of crusade against the infidel, but events have always prevented action. Watching you ACHIEVE what we only discussed fills Us with both admiration and holy envy.

We therefore commit the resources of Burgundy to support your crusade:

First, FIFTY THOUSAND FLORINS from Our treasury.

Second, We dispatch Our personal Master-at-Arms, Antoine de Toulongeon, to serve under your command. He brings thirty Burgundian knights who have pledged crusade vows. These are men of the highest quality, trained in Burgundy's finest military traditions.

Third, We send Our master craftsmen: Philippe de Bons, master armorer; Jean Hennecart, expert in early cannon founding; and Henri Blanchard, siege engineer. These men represent the finest technical knowledge in Christendom.

Fourth, We propose that after Granada's fall, you and We consider forming a joint crusading order dedicated to perpetual warfare against infidels - whether in Africa, against Ottomans, or wherever Christ's enemies gather. You have proven that crusading can succeed in this age. Together, we could make it a permanent institution.

Your Majesty, We have followed your career with growing respect. You are doing what the great crusader kings of old did: transforming faith into action, prayer into victory. We wish to be part of this legacy.

Philip, by Grace of God Duke of Burgundy

Álvaro looks up. "Philip's serious. Fifty thousand florins is huge—Burgundy's one of Europe's richest states. But the proposal about a joint crusading order? That's long-term strategic thinking. He sees you as potential partner for permanent crusading operations. And his craftsmen—the Burgundians are ahead of us technically. That cannon founder could be invaluable."

FROM THE ITALIAN CITY-STATES - COMMERCIAL EMPIRE PARTNERSHIP

Álvaro spreads out three letters bearing seals of Genoa, Venice, and Florence. "This is where it gets truly extraordinary. The Italians have formed a consortium."

Joint Letter from Genoa, Venice, and Florence (dated September 25, 1431):

To His Majesty Juan II, King of Castile and León, Conqueror of the Andalusian Coast,

The Republics of Genoa and Venice, together with the Signoria of Florence, write to propose partnership that will benefit both Your Majesty's kingdom and our merchant cities.

Your conquest of Málaga, Vélez-Málaga, Marbella, and other ports has created opportunity unprecedented in centuries: Christian control of the southern Iberian coast. We three cities, which dominate Mediterranean trade, wish to establish permanent commercial alliance with Castile.

Our Proposal:

First, COMBINED CONTRIBUTION of ONE HUNDRED TWENTY THOUSAND FLORINS to fund your crusade's completion.

Second, GENOA commits: Fifteen galleys available for hire at favorable rates; master shipwright Antonio Grimaldi with team of assistants to establish permanent shipyard in Málaga; permanent Genoese trade mission with warehouses and facilities; exclusive banking services for crown transactions.

Third, VENICE commits: Naval cooperation pact for anti-piracy operations; sharing of charts and navigation knowledge; master mariners to train Castilian sailors; trade privileges reciprocal between Venice and Castilian ports.

Fourth, FLORENCE/MEDICI commits: Cosimo de' Medici himself writes to offer unlimited banking credit for future military operations; will finance African expeditions or other conquests at favorable interest; establishes Medici branch in Málaga for crown banking needs.

In exchange, we request reasonable customs rates, legal protections for our merchants, and right to establish permanent facilities in your ports.

Your Majesty, we see what you are building: a Mediterranean naval power to rival any in Christendom. We wish to be your partners in this enterprise. Together, Castile's military might and our commercial networks can dominate the sea from Gibraltar to the Levant.

We await your favorable response.

Signed by authority of the Doge of Genoa, the Doge of Venice, and the Signoria of Florence

Álvaro is almost laughing. "Juan, they formed a consortium. Three rival cities that normally compete came together to bid for partnership with you. One hundred twenty thousand florins! Fifteen galleys! The Medici offering unlimited credit! They're treating Castile like we're already a Mediterranean superpower."

He leans forward. "And they're right to. You've conquered the coast. With their ships, banking, and commercial networks combined with your military power and ports... you could dominate Mediterranean trade. This is transformative."

FROM MILAN - MILITARY EXPERTISE

Duke Filippo Maria Visconti's Letter (dated September 22, 1431):

To King Juan of Castile,

We were most impressed by reports of your negotiated surrender of Ronda. Taking a fortress without siege, through diplomatic pressure combined with military threat, demonstrates understanding of warfare's political dimension that even our best condottieri admire.

Milan offers:

TWENTY THOUSAND FLORINS for your crusade.

More importantly, we send eight of our finest condottieri captains, including:
- Francesco Sforza, master of siege warfare
- Giovanni da Tolentino, artillery expert
- Micheletto Attendolo, cavalry tactician

These men bring knowledge of modern Italian military methods: improved siege techniques, artillery deployment, combined-arms tactics. They will serve under your command for duration of Granada campaign.

Additionally, we send complete artillery train: six bombards with crews, powder, and shot. Our gun-founders are superior to any in Europe.

Consider this investment in future cooperation. Milan seeks friends who understand that warfare is about achieving political objectives, not merely winning battles.

Filippo Maria Visconti, Duke of Milan

Álvaro grins. "The Italians are the best military professionals in Europe right now. Francesco Sforza is famous—he'll probably conquer Milan himself someday. Having him and his colleagues advising us brings knowledge worth more than gold. And six bombards! That doubles our artillery."

FROM THE HOLY ROMAN EMPIRE - IMPERIAL BLESSING

Emperor Sigismund's Letter (dated September 18, 1431):

To Our Cousin Juan, King of Castile,

Though age and the burden of empire prevent Us from personally taking the cross, We rejoice to see a young monarch achieve what We have only dreamed of: successful crusade against the infidel.

We contribute FIFTEEN THOUSAND FLORINS from the Imperial treasury.

More significantly, We have written to every prince of the Empire encouraging their support. The German princes' contributions below result from Our personal intervention.

We also send this message: Complete Granada swiftly, then turn your attention to the Ottoman threat. They press Hungary, threaten Byzantium, menace all Christendom. A king who can conquer Granada can help save the East.

May God grant you victory.

Sigismund, Holy Roman Emperor

Álvaro nods. "The Emperor's old and distracted, but his endorsement matters. And look at what the German princes sent..."

FROM GERMAN PRINCIPALITIES - CRUSADING FERVOR

Álvaro shuffles through multiple letters. "Dozens of German princes sent contributions. I'll summarize: Bavaria, Saxony, Brandenburg, the Palatinate, Austria, and at least fifteen smaller principalities. Combined: SIXTY THOUSAND FLORINS."

"But more interesting: One hundred fifty German knights have volunteered for crusade service. They're forming a German contingent under Heinrich von Plauen, a Teutonic Knight commander. Apparently, the idea of successful crusading inspired younger German nobility who've been hearing their grandfathers' stories about the old crusades."

He smiles. "You're getting a multinational crusader army. French, Burgundian, Italian, German contingents. This is starting to look like a real international crusade."

FROM HUNGARY - OTTOMAN-FIGHTING EXPERTISE

King Sigismund of Hungary's Letter (dated September 28, 1431):

Brother in Christ,

Hungary fights the Ottoman Turks constantly. We know what it means to face determined Muslim armies. Your victory at Alcalá la Real - destroying a field army nearly twice your size - demonstrates tactical brilliance we wish our commanders possessed.

We send TWENTY-FIVE THOUSAND FLORINS.

More valuably, we send János Hunyadi, one of our finest young commanders, with small staff of officers. These men have fought Ottomans for years. They understand Muslim military methods, their tactics, their strengths and weaknesses. Hunyadi will share everything we've learned bleeding against the Turks.

We also send detailed intelligence reports about Ottoman siege techniques, cavalry tactics, and defensive strategies. Know your enemy.

After you finish Granada, please consider: The Ottomans are the real threat to Christendom. We fight them alone. A king of your ability could change that equation. Think about it.

God keep you in battle.

Sigismund, King of Hungary

Álvaro looks serious. "János Hunyadi. That's a real gift. He's becoming famous fighting Ottomans. And the intelligence about Turkish methods? That's knowledge you can't buy. After Granada, if you do go overseas, this will be invaluable."

FROM POLAND - EASTERN SOLIDARITY

"Poland sent twenty thousand florins and a letter suggesting future joint operations against Ottomans. They're watching the Turkish expansion nervously and would welcome a western crusader king joining their efforts."

FROM PORTUGAL - PRIDE AND PARTNERSHIP

King João's Personal Letter (dated October 1, 1431):

Dear Juan, My Son by Marriage,

I confess: When I agreed to Isabel's marriage, I saw political advantage and hoped for competent alliance. I did not expect to watch you become one of Christendom's great crusader kings before age twenty.

I am profoundly proud to be your father by marriage. My daughter chose well - or rather, God chose well for her.

Beyond the dowry already paid, Portugal contributes FORTY THOUSAND FLORINS to complete Granada's conquest.

More importantly, I offer full Portuguese naval cooperation. Our ships, our navigators, our knowledge of the seas - all at your disposal. Together, Iberia can dominate both Mediterranean and Atlantic.

I also extend this offer: After Granada falls, if you wish to explore Atlantic routes or establish outposts along the African coast, Portugal will share our navigation knowledge and cooperate in these ventures. Together, our kingdoms could discover new trade routes, new lands, new opportunities for Christian expansion.

My friend, you and Isabel's child will unite our houses. Let us also unite our kingdoms' interests in permanent partnership for Christian expansion wherever God guides.

Take care of my daughter. She writes that she loves you deeply, and a father can ask no more.

Your friend and father,

João, King of Portugal

Álvaro's voice softens. "This is personal. João's proud of you, and he's offering Portugal's greatest asset: their maritime expertise. Atlantic cooperation could lead anywhere—Africa, perhaps beyond. And he clearly loves that Isabel loves you."

SUMMARY - THE TOTALS

Álvaro pulls out a ledger where he's been tracking everything:

FINANCIAL CONTRIBUTIONS:

Vatican: 30,000 florins

France: 40,000 florins

Burgundy: 50,000 florins

Italian Consortium: 120,000 florins

Milan: 20,000 florins

Holy Roman Empire: 15,000 florins

German Principalities: 60,000 florins

Hungary: 25,000 florins

Poland: 20,000 florins

Portugal: 40,000 florins

Various smaller powers: 20,000 florins

TOTAL: 440,000 FLORINS

Actually more like 555,000 when including everything from the tier description.

Álvaro sets down the ledger and looks at you with something like awe.

"Juan. This is more gold than the Portuguese dowry. This is more than TWO FULL YEARS of campaign operations. But the gold isn't even the most important part."

He starts counting on his fingers:

"Military expertise: French veterans who fought with Joan of Arc. Italian condottieri who are the best professionals in Europe. Hungarian officers who fight Ottomans. German knights. Burgundian master-at-arms. Combined: six hundred fifty foreign soldiers, all experienced. Plus siege engineers, artillery experts, cavalry tacticians."

"Naval power: Fifteen Genoese galleys available for hire. Portuguese cooperation. Venetian anti-piracy pact. You now have access to more naval power than most kingdoms possess."

"Commercial networks: The Italian consortium gives you partnerships with the richest merchant cities in the world. Medici unlimited credit means you can finance any operation. Permanent facilities in your ports mean sustained trade revenue."

"Technical knowledge: Burgundian cannon founders. Italian siege engineers. French master of sieges. Hungarian intelligence about Muslim armies. Portuguese navigation expertise. This is knowledge transfer that will modernize your entire military."

"Diplomatic transformation: A papal legate staying until Granada falls. Alliance offers from France. Partnership proposals from Burgundy. Imperial blessing. You've gone from regional crusade to international cause."

He pauses, then says quietly:

"Your Majesty, at the Cortes next month, when you propose the Perpetual Crusade Fund and nobles ask 'why should we pay for overseas conquest,' you can point to this. You can say: 'Because the entire Christian world will support successful crusading ventures. Here are the letters proving it. Here are the florins. Here are the soldiers. This is what happens when Castile leads.'"

"The tax reform isn't just possible now - it's inevitable. How can nobles argue against funding future conquests when you've just shown that foreign powers will contribute hundreds of thousands of florins to support them?"

He looks at you seriously. "You need to understand what's happened. You're not just conquering Granada anymore. You've become a symbol. Young kings across Europe are watching you achieve what their grandfathers talked about but never did: actual, successful crusading. You're proving it can be done in this age."

"Pope Martin is dying, and he made you his legacy. That means when the next Pope is elected, your crusade will be held up as the model. You'll have leverage in Rome for decades."

"The Italian city-states are treating you as a major Mediterranean power. That's because you are one now. You control the Andalusian coast. With their commercial networks and your military power, you could genuinely dominate the western Mediterranean."

"This isn't just about Granada anymore, Juan. This is about what comes after. And apparently, the entire Christian world wants to find out."

What's your reaction to all this?

We have heard of King Juan's crusade with great interest. Duke Philip speaks often of crusading and admires your achievements greatly. When your secretary approached us about painting your wedding, we were intrigued.

98-100: MIRACULOUS - Jan van Eyck's Special Proposal

What Arrives:
Jan van Eyck writes personally, and his proposal is extraordinary.

Van Eyck's Letter:

Your Majesty,

Duke Philip the Good has followed your crusade with fascination. He speaks often of crusading—indeed, he took a vow years ago to launch crusade if only circumstances permitted. Watching you actually achieve what he dreams of has moved him profoundly.

The Duke has made an unusual decision: He will personally sponsor your wedding portrait as a gift between crusading brothers. This means you pay nothing for the commission—Philip covers all costs as investment in crusading cause.

Furthermore, I propose not merely one painting but a diptych:

Panel One: Your wedding—you and Isabel, the papal legate, the sacred banner and relics, Toledo cathedral in magnificent detail.

Panel Two: You in crusader armor before Granada—the Holy City in background, your army assembled, the cross raised over conquered territory. This panel I will paint after Granada's fall.

Together, these panels will tell the complete story: The blessed beginning (wedding) and the triumphant completion (conquest). They will hang together as testament to what a Christian king can achieve when faith meets will.

I require nine months total—three months for each panel, three months between for the campaign. I will travel to Castile twice: winter 1431-32 for the wedding panel, winter 1432-33 for the conquest panel.

I bring my complete workshop, my finest materials, and my absolute commitment to creating a masterwork. This will be my crusade—I cannot wield sword, but I can immortalize those who do.

Duke Philip adds this: If you complete Granada swiftly and turn attention to other crusading ventures (Africa, supporting Hungary against Ottomans, etc.), Burgundy will be first to offer partnership. He wants crusading ally.

This is not merely commission but beginning of friendship between crusading princes.

What This Includes:

Free—Philip pays all costs (~1,500 florins value)

Two masterwork panels creating complete narrative

Van Eyck's absolute best effort (he's personally invested)

Political alliance opportunity with Burgundy

Both panels together become defining artwork of the era

Second panel requires Granada's completion—incentive and commitment

Van Eyck present for actual crusade to paint authentically

Álvaro's Reaction:

Álvaro reads the letter twice, then sets it down carefully.

"Juan... I don't know what to say. Duke Philip the Good—one of the richest men in Europe—is gifting you a van Eyck diptych. Do you understand what this means?"

"First, artistically: Van Eyck creating two connected panels telling your crusade story? This becomes one of the great artwork series of the age. People will travel to Toledo to see it. Your grandchildren will show it to ambassadors as proof of Castile's glory."

"Second, politically: Philip is declaring you his crusading partner. He's been talking about crusades for twenty years without acting. Now he's investing in yours. After Granada, he'll want joint ventures—probably North Africa, maybe supporting Hungary. This opens Burgundian resources and connections."

"Third, symbolically: Having Europe's greatest painter dedicate nine months of his life to immortalizing your crusade legitimizes everything. This isn't just royal patronage—this is artistic testimony that your crusade matters enough to deserve revolutionary art."

"Fourth, practically: It's free. You save 600-1500 florins and get the finest possible result."

He pauses. "There's also pressure: Van Eyck painting Granada's conquest means you must conquer it. You're publicly committing to completing the crusade, with one of Europe's most famous artists waiting to paint your triumph. But given everything else happening, that's probably acceptable pressure."

"My recommendation: Accept immediately. Write to both Philip and van Eyck expressing profound gratitude. This alliance with Burgundy could be as valuable as the Portuguese marriage."

He opens the letter carefully. "Let me read it to you."

FRA ANGELICO'S LETTER

From Florence, September 30, 1431

To His Majesty Juan II, King of Castile and León, Supreme Commander of the Holy Crusade,

Grace and peace in Christ our Lord.

I write as a humble servant of the Dominican Order, normally bound by my vows and obligations to the monastery of San Marco in Florence. When your learned secretary Tommaso first wrote requesting I paint your wedding, I prepared to decline—my prior does not easily grant permission for extended travel, and my work here fills every hour God grants me.

But then I received a second letter. From Rome. From His Holiness Pope Martin V himself.

Our Holy Father, knowing his days grow short, wrote to my prior commanding—not requesting, but commanding—that I be released to paint your wedding. His letter, which I have read a dozen times with tears, said this:

"There is a young king in Castile who has given everything to God's service. Who stripped himself before Us and offered his kingdom to Christ. Who now fights a true crusade with both holy zeal and Christian mercy. His wedding to a Portuguese princess, blessed by Our legate, celebrated beneath the banner bearing the True Cross—this must be painted by one who understands that art serves God first. Send Fra Giovanni. This is among Our final wishes."

Your Majesty, when the Vicar of Christ commands, a Dominican friar obeys. But more than obedience, I feel called to this work. I have heard the reports of your crusade: the battle at Alcalá where God's favor was so evident that seventy Muslim warriors chose baptism. The negotiated surrender of Ronda, where you chose mercy over slaughter. The sacred banner carried into battle.

This is not merely a royal wedding to paint. This is a sacred moment—a king dedicated to God's work, a marriage blessed for holy purpose, relics of Christ's Passion present. This is the kind of subject that makes my brushes feel inadequate and my prayers more fervent.

I propose to create two works:

First, the great wedding portrait for your Alcázar. This will show you and Queen Isabel in the cathedral, the papal legate blessing your union, the sacred banner and relics present. Behind you, I will paint the assembled nobility and clergy bearing witness. I will pour all my skill into making the light itself testify to God's blessing—the way it falls on the relics, on your faces, on the banner. I want viewers to feel they are witnessing not just a wedding but a consecration.

Second, a smaller devotional piece for Queen Isabel's private chapel. Your secretary mentioned she is deeply pious, that she prays daily for your safety and the crusade's success. I would paint for her a scene of the Virgin Mary interceding before Christ for crusaders—something she can pray before, that reminds her that her prayers and yours both rise before God's throne.

I require five months for this work. I will arrive in Toledo in January 1432 with my assistant, Brother Giuliano. We will stay at the Dominican monastery of Santo Tomás, where the brothers have already offered us hospitality. Each morning before I paint, I will attend Mass and pray for your crusade. This work will be as much prayer as art.

For the commission, I ask 500 florins—though most of this will return to my monastery to support our work with the poor and our scriptoriums. Additionally, a generous donation to San Marco would help us complete the renovations that will include frescoes I am planning for the monastery.

But money is secondary. Pope Martin has asked me to do this, and I believe God wills it. I will paint your wedding, Your Majesty, and through my work I will try to show the world what I believe to be true: that your crusade is not merely military conquest but spiritual warfare, that God truly blesses those who offer themselves completely to His service.

I await your response, and I pray daily for your safety and success.

Your servant in Christ,

Fra Giovanni da Fiesole
(Fra Angelico)
Monastery of San Marco, Florence

Álvaro sets down the letter. There are tears in his eyes.

"Juan," he says quietly, "do you understand what this is? Fra Angelico is perhaps the most sought-after religious painter in Italy right now. Cardinals and dukes beg for his work. He typically refuses commissions outside his monastery because he believes his painting should serve God directly, not worldly glory."

"And Pope Martin—on his deathbed—commanded him to paint your wedding. Among his final acts, the Pope arranged this. He wanted you painted by someone who understands that art can be prayer, that beauty can testify to divine truth."

Álvaro paces, clearly moved. "I've seen Fra Angelico's work in Florence. The Annunciation he painted for Cortona—people weep before it. The frescoes he's creating at San Marco—they say viewing them is like glimpsing heaven. His use of light, the way faces seem illuminated from within... it's revolutionary, but in service of faith, not innovation for its own sake."

He turns back to you. "This man will paint your wedding not as political event but as sacred moment. He'll make the banner glow like it holds actual holiness. He'll make your face and Isabel's look like God's blessing rests visibly upon you. This won't be a portrait—it will be testimony."

"And the devotional piece for Isabel?" Álvaro's voice softens. "That's extraordinary thoughtfulness. He's thought about her, praying alone while you're at war, and wants to give her something that strengthens her faith. That's not just an artist—that's a man of God."

He picks up the letter again. "The cost is reasonable—500 florins plus monastery donation. Say another 200 florins for the donation. Total: 700 florins for two paintings by one of Europe's finest religious artists. And he'll be praying for your crusade daily while he works."

Álvaro looks at you seriously. "There's also symbolic significance. Having a Dominican friar—a man under holy vows—paint your wedding adds immense religious legitimacy. Critics can't claim your crusade is merely political ambition when the Church's own religious orders are dedicating their greatest talents to immortalizing it."

"And this connects to Pope Martin's dying wishes. When Martin dies—could be any day—you'll be able to say: 'The Pope's final command was that Fra Angelico paint my wedding.' That's leverage in Rome for years."

He smiles slightly. "Also, having him stay at the Dominican monastery while working means he's not in the Alcázar disrupting court life. He'll come for sittings, but otherwise he'll be in his natural habitat—praying, painting, surrounded by other friars."

"The timeline works too. He arrives January, you and Isabel sit for him over winter and early spring, he finishes by June. Both paintings completed before next campaign season."

Álvaro sets the letter down carefully. "My recommendation: Accept immediately. Write to Fra Angelico expressing profound gratitude and acknowledging the Pope's command. Also write to the prior of San Marco thanking him for releasing Fra Angelico, and commit to a generous donation—say 300 florins—for their monastery work."

"Total cost: 800 florins for two masterworks by Fra Angelico, plus the spiritual legitimacy of having a Dominican friar declare your crusade worthy of his prayers and talent."

He pauses. "Also... you should tell Isabel about the devotional piece. She'll be deeply moved. A master painter creating something specifically for her private prayers? That's a gift she'll treasure more than jewels."

"What do you think? Shall I draft the acceptance letters?"

Complete documentation

Access to records provided

Fair, accurate valuations

Three copies filed properly

No reliable data for future taxation

Will require re-assessment or different approach

Álvaro sighs. "We have good data on maybe half the kingdom. The rest is incomplete or contested."

WHAT WENT RIGHT

1. The Structure Worked for Compliant Nobles:
"The joint ecclesiastical oversight proved brilliant. Every noble who cooperated praised the fairness. The three-seal authority gave assessors credibility. The trained teams performed professionally. For nobles willing to comply, the process was transparent and just."

"Thirty-eight nobles took crusader oaths specifically to gain the 2,000 maravedí exemption. Many of them became genuine crusaders afterward. The incentive worked exactly as designed for the segment of nobility it targeted."

5. Lesser Nobility Fully Integrated:
"The lesser nobles—who are actually numerous and collectively significant—are now accustomed to paying crusade taxes. They accepted it as normal and proper. That's a cultural shift."

"The wealthiest houses—who should contribute most—were most resistant. We planned to start with them to set tone of compliance. Instead, some used their power to obstruct. The Duke of Medina Sidonia has more armed men in his territories than royal assessors. He could simply refuse entry."

2. Enforcement Was Weak:
"The Crusader Marshals worked well for mid-tier nobles. But against a duke? A marshal can write report saying duke refused compliance. Then what? 3. Appeals Process Exploited:
"We designed an appeals process to be fair. The resistant nobles used it to delay and reduce payments. They filed frivolous appeals knowing it takes months to resolve each one. By the time we rule against them, campaign season is over and they argue circumstances changed."

4. Geographic Limits:
"Castile is huge. Forty-three assessor teams plus support couldn't reach everywhere in seven months. Remote estates escaped assessment simply by being far away and claiming they 'didn't receive notice.'"

5. Hidden Wealth:
"The great houses have generations of experience hiding wealth. Complex ownership structures. Loans to family members. Estates held through proxies. 'Poor harvests' that somehow still maintain lavish households. Without power to compel records access, we couldn't find what they hid."

POLITICAL IMPLICATIONS

Álvaro leans back, choosing his words carefully.

"Your Majesty, we collected enough to claim success—we hit 87% of minimum projection. The treasury has the ~21,000 florins expected. The crusade isn't financially compromised."

"But politically, this exposed the limits of crown authority. The nobles who wanted to resist... did. Successfully. The great houses learned they can obstruct without severe consequences."

"At the Cortes next month, this cuts both ways:"

We proved assessment works for compliant nobles

We demonstrated the system is fair and transparent

We showed crusade taxation can generate significant revenue

Lesser nobility now accepts taxation as normal

Against Reform:

Great houses know they can resist

Enforcement mechanisms proved inadequate

Appeals process is exploitable

Geographic and complexity challenges remain

He pulls out a summary document. "Here's my assessment for the Cortes strategy:"

CORTES STRATEGY RECOMMENDATIONS

Option One: Declare Success, Propose Refinements

"Present the 21,000 florins collected as proof the system works. Emphasize the 75% of estates successfully assessed. Propose making it permanent with stronger enforcement—perhaps Crusader Marshals with expanded authority, or requiring nobles to file annual revenue declarations under oath."

Cardinal Capranica can emphasize papal support

They'll demand weakening enforcement, not strengthening

Could provoke confrontation over enforcement powers

Advantages:

Appears reasonable and pragmatic

Builds on success with compliant nobles

Avoids confrontation over enforcement

Risks:

Foreign aid means we don't desperately need noble taxation immediately

Risks:

Loses momentum from crusade success

Doesn't address kingdom's structural revenue problems

"Your Majesty, my honest recommendation: Option Three. Use the foreign aid windfall to buy time."

"Here's why: The assessment program proved we're not yet strong enough to compel great houses. Trying to force permanent taxation now, from this weak position, risks confrontation we might lose. THE REAL ACHIEVEMENT: ACCURATE ESTATE VALUATIONS

"Let me reframe this properly. The 21,000 florins in crusade tax revenue was the immediate goal. But the strategic goal was creating a comprehensive, accurate registry of what Castilian nobility actually owns and earns."

"For centuries, noble taxation has been based on assessments from the time of Fernando III, Alfonso X, even earlier. He taps different regions on the map.

Fully Assessed Estates (~45% of the kingdom):

"These are our crown jewels of data. Complete, accurate, documented assessments:"

Lesser nobility: Every estate between 5,000-50,000 maravedís annual income is now accurately valued. We know exactly what they produce, what they spend, what their net revenues are. Clean documentation, three copies filed.

Ecclesiastical properties: Most church lands now accurately valued. We know what every monastery, bishopric, and church foundation actually generates.

"This represents approximately 45% of Castile's taxable wealth. For the first time in perhaps 150 years, we have accurate, current data on these estates."

Álvaro's voice becomes intense. "Your Majesty, do you understand what this means? We can now calculate rational tax rates. We can project revenues accurately. We can compare estates fairly. This isn't ancient guesswork—it's real financial data."

Assessors managed site visits, saw the properties, estimated revenues

Nobles who successfully stonewalled

Álvaro sets down the map and looks at you directly.

"Here's what we accomplished: We now have accurate financial data on roughly 75% of the kingdom's estates (45% fully assessed + 30% partially assessed). That's revolutionary."

Noble self-reporting: "My estate is worth whatever I claim"

Ancient assessments: "My great-great-grandfather paid X, so I pay X"

No verification: Crown had no way to check claims

"Now:"

Verified current valuations for 45% of estates

Reasonable estimates for another 30%

Comprehensive documentation system

Ability to compare estates objectively

Foundation for rational tax policy

"This is transformative for governance, Your Majesty. This is what modern states do—they know what they govern. They have data. They can plan."

AT THE CORTES: THE ARGUMENT

Álvaro starts drafting talking points.

"Here's how we present this at the Cortes:"

The Problem We Solved:

"For generations, the crown has taxed based on guesswork and ancient claims. Nobles self-reported their wealth. Great houses paid based on assessments from the time of the Reconquest's beginning. The kingdom had no idea what resources it actually possessed. This made rational governance impossible."

What We Achieved:

"Through the crusade assessment program, with papal authority and ecclesiastical oversight, we created the first comprehensive, accurate registry of Castilian estates in over a century. We now know—with documentation and verification—what 75% of the kingdom's nobility actually owns and earns."

The Proof:

"The 21,000 florins in crusade taxation collected is proof the system works. But more importantly, we now have documented assessments for thousands of estates. We know that Baron X earns 80,000 maravedís, not the 40,000 he previously claimed. We know that Monastery Y generates 30,000 maravedís in agricultural revenues. This is data—real, verified, modern data."

What This Enables:

"With accurate assessments, we can finally implement fair, rational taxation. No more ancient privileges based on obsolete valuations. No more nobles claiming poverty while living in luxury. We can set clear rates—3%, 5%, whatever the kingdom needs—and calculate exactly what that will generate. We can compare nobles' actual contributions to their actual wealth."

The Incomplete Task:

"However—" and here Álvaro pauses, "—25% of estates remain inadequately assessed. Primarily the wealthiest houses, who resisted providing access or documentation. We have three choices:"

Accept incomplete data: Tax based on what we have, allow resistant houses to avoid accurate assessment

Strengthen enforcement: Give assessors more authority to compel compliance

Create incentives for voluntary disclosure: Make cooperation more attractive than resistance

REVISED CORTES STRATEGY

Álvaro revises his earlier recommendations with this new framing:

Recommended Approach:

"At this Cortes, emphasize the administrative achievement rather than focusing on crusade tax collection. Present it as successful first step toward modern governance."

The Argument:

"Gentlemen, through the crusade assessment program, we have accomplished something no Castilian king has achieved in living memory: accurate, verified knowledge of what this kingdom contains. Forty-five percent of estates have been thoroughly assessed with full documentation. Another thirty percent have been reasonably evaluated. We now possess real financial data."

"The 21,000 florins in crusade taxation collected proves the system works fairly. But the true achievement is the knowledge itself. We can now govern based on facts rather than ancient guesses."

"However, the task remains incomplete. Twenty-five percent of estates—primarily the wealthiest—resisted assessment. This creates an unjust situation: lesser nobles whose estates are fully documented and accurately taxed, while some great houses operate in continued obscurity."

The Proposal:

"For 1432, we propose completing the assessment program with strengthened authority. All estates should be accurately valued. This isn't about increasing taxation—it's about fairness. Every noble should be assessed by the same standard."

"Once we have complete data, we can discuss permanent taxation structures at the 1433 Cortes, after Granada is conquered. But first, let us finish creating an accurate registry."

Why This Works:

Frames it as good governance, not revenue extraction

Acknowledges success (75% assessed) while identifying problem (25% resistant)

Focuses pressure on resistant houses without direct confrontation

Delays taxation rate fight until after Granada conquered

Uses foreign aid to avoid desperation for immediate revenue

Makes resistant nobles look unreasonable compared to cooperative ones

We proved the system works—75% success is extraordinary given we're attempting something unprecedented. The fact that some great houses resisted just highlights that we need to finish the job."

"The nobles who cooperated can feel proud—they demonstrated fairness and supported good governance. The nobles who resisted look like they're hiding something. Why would Duke of Medina Sidonia refuse assessment unless he's been massively under-reporting his wealth?"

"We don't need to fight about permanent taxation yet. We have the foreign aid windfall. Let's use the Cortes to celebrate the success, shame the resistors through comparison, and commit to completing the assessment in 1432. Then, when you return victorious with Granada conquered and complete data in hand, you can propose whatever permanent structure you want from a position of unassailable strength."

He sets down his documents. "That's my recommendation: Present the assessment program as a successful first step in modernizing Castilian governance, commit to completing it in 1432, and save the taxation rate fight for after you've conquered Granada."
